concept.title: Risks and Precautions in Typewriter Lubrication
concept.shortdesc: There are important precautions for lubricating a typewriter, as improper lubrication can cause mechanical damage, attract debris, or create safety hazards during typewriter maintenance.

ul.li: Excessive lubrication attracts dust, lint, and debris, forming sticky residue that restricts the movement of components.
Heavy oils such as motor oil, WD-40, or household lubricants are too viscous for delicate mechanisms and can solidify, leading to seized parts.
Rubber components such as the platen, rollers, or feeders degrade when exposed to oil, resulting in cracking and residue transfer to the ribbon and paper.
Exposed mechanisms, including the segment, vibrator, and line-spacing assemblies, collect dust when oiled, reducing performance and increasing maintenance needs.
Aerosol lubricants and solvent-based sprays dissolve paint and decals and leave films that cause long-term residue buildup.
Oils and cleaning agents emit fumes that can irritate skin and lungs and may be flammable in enclosed spaces.

conbody.note: Using small amounts of light oil only on essential metal connections minimizes wear without attracting debris or causing damage to exposed or rubber components.
